Unsigned Short Int   2           Unsigned Char      1

3. Decision Statements

4. Iterative

++/--;} //entry control loop

++/--;}
while(condition); //exit control loop

Functions

  1. Call by Value: Original value not changed
  2. Call by Reference: Original value is modified since we pass address.
  3. Call by Address: Changes made to the parameter affects the arguments.

OOPs Concepts

    1.Classes:
     -Blue print of an object.
     -A real time entity.
     -Grouping data and functions into single unit.
    Syntax: class book
    { int age;
      int rollno;
    };

    ModifiersOwn classDerived classMain()
    Public   Yes   Yes   Yes
    Private   Yes   No   No
    Protected   Yes   Yes   No


    2. Objects:
     -Instance of a class
     -When a class is defined, no memory allocated to object but once instantiated, memory allocated.
    Syntax:class person
    {char name[20];
    int id;
    public: void getdetail(){}
    };
    int main(){
    person p1;//object
    }

    3. Encapsulation
     -Wrapping up of data and information in single unit.
     -Leads to data abstraction or hiding.

    4. Abstraction
     -Dispaying only essential details and hiding implementation.
     -Providing only essential information about data to the outside world.

    5. Polymorphism
     -Having many forms.
     -Abiity of a message to be displayed in more than one forms.
     
    • Compile Time Polymorphism
      •  Function Overloading
       Operator Overloading
    • Run Time Polymorphism
      •  Virtual Funtion


    6. Inheritance
     -Child class inherits the properties of base class.
     -Code reusability is increased and there is no need to writr same code again and again.
    Syntax: class subclass_name: access_mode baseclass_name{
    //body of subclass
    };

Constructors

1. It is a special member function of a class having same name as class name.
2. It has no return type.

There are three types of constructors:-

a)Default Constructor
b)Parameterized Constructor
c)Copy Constructor

i)Shallow copy constructors
ii)Deep copy constructor
